content.text: To establish a proactive and systematic framework for identifying, assessing, mitigating, and responding to risks that could impact the safety, wellbeing, and operational continuity of the school, ensuring a secure environment for all stakeholders.
The school employs a continuous four-stage risk management cycle to proactively manage potential threats.

items.title: Identify
points: Proactively identify potential risks across all operational domains through brainstorming, audits, and incident reviews.

items.title: Assess
points: Analyze risks based on their likelihood and potential impact (severity) using a risk assessment matrix.

items.title: Mitigate & Control
points: Develop and implement strategies to reduce the likelihood or impact of identified risks. This includes preventative measures, contingency plans, and control systems.

items.title: Monitor & Review
points: Regularly review the effectiveness of mitigation strategies and update the risk register. This process is reviewed annually or after any significant incident.

content.text: Risks are categorized to ensure comprehensive coverage. The school maintains a formal Risk Register, which is a live document reviewed quarterly by the leadership team.

content.title: Key Risk Categories
items: Health & Safety: Student/staff injuries, illness outbreaks, food safety, building hazards.
Safeguarding & Child Protection: Bullying, abuse, online safety threats.
Operational: Staff turnover, IT system failure, utility disruption, transportation incidents.
Financial: Budget shortfalls, fraud, unexpected capital expenditures.
Reputational: Negative media, parent complaints, social media crises.
Compliance: Failure to meet Ministry, Cambridge, or accreditation standards.
Natural Disasters: Earthquakes, floods, fires, extreme weather.

content.text: The ERP provides clear, actionable procedures for responding to critical incidents. The plan is designed to protect life, stabilize the incident, and facilitate a return to normal operations.

roles.title: Principal/Director
resp: CMT Leader, final decision-maker, primary spokesperson.

roles.title: Head of Operations/Facilities
resp: Manages on-the-ground response, logistics, and site security.

roles.title: Head of Academic/Vice Principal
resp: Responsible for student and staff accountability and welfare.

roles.title: School Counselor/Head of Pastoral
resp: Leads psychological first aid and post-crisis support.

roles.title: Communications Officer
resp: Manages all internal and external communications.

content.text: Clear, color-coded procedures are established for different types of emergencies. These are displayed in all classrooms and common areas.

content.title: Standard Response Protocols
items: Evacuation: Used for fire, gas leaks, or structural concerns. Move to designated assembly points.
Lockdown: Used for a threat or hazard inside the building. All doors are locked, and occupants remain silent and out of sight.
Shelter-in-Place: Used for external hazards like severe weather or air quality issues. Occupants remain indoors.
Medical Emergency: Procedures for responding to serious injuries or health crises, including contacting emergency services and designated first aiders.

content.text: Detailed, site-specific maps showing evacuation routes, assembly points, first aid kits, and fire extinguishers are posted throughout the campus.
Timely and accurate communication is critical during an emergency. The school uses a multi-channel approach.

items.title: Initial Alert (Internal)
points: Public address (PA) system, school-wide alarm, or internal messaging app to alert staff and students.

items.title: Parent/Guardian Notification
points: Initial notification via SMS blast or school app (e.g., EduNav) with basic information and instructions. Follow-up emails provide more detail as it becomes available.

items.title: Media & Public
points: All media inquiries are directed to the designated spokesperson (Principal/Director). Official statements are posted on the school website.

items.title: Post-Incident Communication
points: Debriefing sessions for staff, students, and parents. Counseling support information is shared.

content.text: Preparedness is maintained through regular training and practice.

items: Drills: Fire, earthquake, and lockdown drills are conducted at least twice per academic year.
Staff Training: Annual training for all staff on ERP procedures, including first aid and fire extinguisher use.
CMT Training: The Crisis Management Team undergoes annual tabletop exercises to simulate and practice responding to various scenarios.
Post-Drill/Incident Review: Every drill and actual incident is followed by a debriefing session to identify lessons learned and improve the ERP.

content.text: To demonstrate compliance and preparedness, the school maintains:

items: The official Risk Register, updated quarterly.
The comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP) document.
Drill schedule and log, including evaluation reports for each drill.
Minutes from Crisis Management Team meetings and post-incident reviews.
Records of staff training on safety and emergency procedures.
Building safety inspection certificates (e.g., fire safety, structural integrity).
Communication templates for various emergency scenarios.
CIS Standards: Domain B (Guiding Statements) and Domain G (Wellbeing).
WASC Category A: Organization for Student Learning, and Category C: Support for Student Personal and Academic Growth.
Indonesian Law on Child Protection (No. 35/2014) and Disaster Management (No. 24/2007).
School's duty of care to provide a safe and secure environment for all members of the community.
